column4: I'm trying to do an EOL upgrade from Jaunty to Karmic, and am following this documentation:   https://help.ubuntu.com/community/EOLUpgrades/Jaunty .    I'm  trying to do "sudo do-release-upgrade",  however it says command not found.  Any ideas?
yep
I'll run it again
nope, still not found
Are you running a server? You require at least update-manager-core to use do-release-upgrade
yes, running a server
Install update-manager-core and retry
thanks, that was it.   Although, now I'm getting this:  http://pastie.org/2510715

Might be because you're using a non-LTS release and you're trying to jump straight to Lucid, skipping 9.10. You might have to change your settings to go to 9.10 and then 10.04, then set it back to LTS-only
I'm  just following this:  https://help.ubuntu.com/community/EOLUpgrades/Jaunty
Why 8000? Why not 80 or 8080?
because that's the port that's in use.  I want to know what's using it.
Use a different port?
that's not my question.
I want to know how to find out what is using that port.
netstat can show open ports. However, it would be simpler (and for a webserver make more sense, since HTTP uses 80 and 8080) to use another port
django's default web develeopment port is port 8000,  also known as http-alt
80 is standard http, 8080 is alternate, not 8000
well,  NMAP reports it as http-alt.  Either way, does it matter?   it's the standard for Django.

I'm just saying the standard for http is 80, or 8080 sometimes. Since your 8000 is being used by something, it would be better to just configure the webserver to use another port rather than stop whatever is using 8000 which if you want to maintain over time if it's a service, you'll need to reconfigure that anyway

I've been using Django for 3 years.   Port 8000 is not generally used by anything else.  I'm assuming my current problem is that there's another django webserver running somewhere.   Hence the reason I would like to find the process and kill it.
Look in service --status-all, and ps -A for the process. If so, perhaps use that webserver instead of a new one, assuming Django can host multiple sites.
it's a development server, not a system-wide service.
nm, finally found it.
